question:
What is a one-sentence summary of the following article?
The American Academy of Micropigmentation and the Society of Permanent Cosmetic Professionals provide microblading certification to much of the English-speaking world. As such, look for training classes approved by at least one of the two boards, meaning they follow the organization’s official regulations and are run by a society-certified instructor. The SPCP and AAM maintain lists of certified trainers on their official websites. Due to microblading’s boom in popularity, lots of for-profit training classes have popped up around the world. Avoid classes that are under 100 hours long or make no mention of the AAM or SPCP. Though some of these classes provide accurate training, many are scams and few will get you closer to official certification. Scam courses are often less than 6 days long, extremely cheap, or advertise the inclusion of a free microblading kit. After finding a good class, enroll with the instructor, pay any required fees, and attend. Expect to work for at least 100 hours with the time divided into class study, homework, live practice, and teacher demonstrations. If AAM and SPCP trainers do not live in your area, travel will most likely be required. Most full courses cost between $4000 and $5000. Expect to take off work for about 1 week in order to attend. Make sure this documentation includes how many hours you worked and has your instructor’s official signature. In addition, with the model or patient’s consent, make sure you take photos of any live work completed. This is essential for both the AAM and SPCP exams, which require proof that you completed 100 hours of training.

Summary:
response: The article emphasizes the importance of choosing microblading training classes approved by the American Academy of Micropigmentation (AAM) or Society of Permanent Cosmetic Professionals (SPCP), as they follow official regulations and are taught by certified instructors, while also warning against potential scams in shorter or cheaper courses.
instruct_model_response: The article discusses the importance of finding a microblading certification training class that is approved by either the American Academy of Micropigmentation or the Society of Permanent Cosmetic Professionals. It advises against taking classes that are less than 100 hours long or do not mention these organizations, as they may be scams. The article also provides information on the requirements for official certification, including working for at least 100 hours with an instructor, taking off work for about a week to attend the course, and providing documentation of the training completed. Additionally, it recommends taking photos of any live work completed for the exams.
openorca_model_response: Ensure you obtain microblading certification from recognized bodies such as the American Academy of Micropigmentation or the Society of Permanent Cosmetic Professionals, by choosing a training course that is at least 100 hours long, is endorsed by either AAM or SPCP, and offered by a society-certified instructor; avoid quick, cheap classes that may be scams. Be prepared to travel, commit to around one week of training, pay a substantial course fee, provide evidence of your training in the form of documentation and photographs, and consider additional practical experience for AAM and SPCP certification exams.

question:
Q:For those of us who struggle with thoughts about our size and shape, sometimes we don’t like our bodies and our behaviour very much. It seems like an impossible task to transform our self loathing into self-love, but it is possible with these five simple steps. I started to write some examples of the self loathing dialogue I occasionally have in my head and I found I couldn’t do it. It felt as wrong as criticising my closest friend. I guess it goes to prove that the shift from loathing to love is not always huge and momentous, but subtle and gradual. When I look in the mirror and see a part of my body I don’t like, I run through these five steps in my head. This following example is the kind of internal conversation I might have about my belly. 1. POSITIVE INTENT (THE GIFT) Recognise the gift your body is giving you. My belly fat is protecting and cushioning my intestines and reproductive system. By having a higher body fat percentage my hormones are functioning as they should, enabling me to have a normal transition through perimenopause. I fit my skin and the wrinkly empty skin folds are gone. 2. FORGIVENESS Acknowledge the way you have treated your body in the past. question:
Grace Brewster Murray Hopper (nee Murray; December 9, 1906 - January 1, 1992) was an American computer scientist and United States Navy rear admiral. One of the first programmers of the Harvard Mark I computer, she was a pioneer of computer programming who invented one of the first compiler related tools. She popularized the idea of machine-independent programming languages, which led to the development of COBOL, an early high-level programming language still in use today. Hopper had attempted to enlist in the Navy during World War II, but she was rejected by the military because she was 34 years of age and thus too old to enlist.

Following her retirement from the Navy, she was hired as a senior consultant to Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC). Hopper was initially offered the job position by Rita Yavinsky, but she insisted on applying for the position at DEC, and going through the typical formal interview process. She also sent a letter to Yavinsky's boss explaining that she would be available on alternating Thursdays, receiving a high salary, and have access to an unlimited expense account if she were to be exhibited at their museum of computing as a pioneer. After the proposal from Hopper, she was hired as a full-time senior consultant. As part of her position, she would report to Yavinsky. In this position, Hopper represented the company at industry forums, serving on various industry committees, along with other obligations. She retained that position until her death at age 85 in 1992.  Hopper was a goodwill ambassador in her primary activity in this capacity. She lectured widely about the early days of computing, her career, and on efforts that computer vendors could take to make life easier for their users. She visited most of Digital's engineering facilities, where she generally received a standing ovation at the conclusion of her remarks.  She often recounted that during her service she was frequently asked by admirals and generals why satellite communication would take so long. So during many of her lectures, she illustrated a nanosecond using salvaged obsolete Bell System 25 pair telephone cable, cut it to 11.8  inch (30  cm) lengths, the distance that light travels in one nanosecond, and handed out the individual wires to her listeners. Although no longer a serving officer, she always wore her Navy full dress uniform to these lectures, which is allowed by US Navy uniform regulations.  The most important thing I've accomplished, other than building the compiler, is training young people. They come to me, you know, and say, 'Do you think we can do this?' I say, "Try it." And I back 'em up. They need that. I keep track of them as they get older and I stir 'em up at intervals so they don't forget to take chances.

Answer the following question by taking a quote from the article: What did she do in this role?
response: In her role as a senior consultant at Digital Equipment Corporation, Grace Hopper served as a goodwill ambassador, representing the company at industry forums and serving on various industry committees. She lectured widely about the early days of computing, her career, and on efforts that computer vendors could take to make life easier for their users. As she often said, "The most important thing I've accomplished, other than building the compiler, is training young people. They come to me, you know, and say, 'Do you think we can do this?' I say, 'Try it.' And I back 'em up. They need that. I keep track of them as they get older and I stir 'em up at intervals so they don't forget to take chances."
instruct_model_response: In her role as a senior consultant at Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC), Grace Hopper represented the company at industry forums, served on various industry committees, and lectured widely about the early days of computing, her career, and on efforts that computer vendors could take to make life easier for their users. She visited most of Digital's engineering facilities and received a standing ovation at the conclusion of her remarks.

She was a goodwill ambassador, widely lecturing about the early days of computing, her career, and on efforts that computer vendors could take to make life easier for their users. She visited most of Digital's engineering facilities and provided encouragement to young people in their endeavors, as stated in the following quote: "The most important thing I've accomplished, other than building the compiler, is training young people. They come to me, you know, and say, 'Do you think we can do this?' I say, 'Try it.' And I back 'em up. They need that. I keep track of them as they get older and I stir 'em up at intervals so they don't forget to take chances."

For example, a brief sentence can be as simple as: "The sky is blue." In this sentence, the subject, "the sky," is paired with the predicate, "is blue," to form a complete thought. Although this sentence is short, it effectively communicates a clear and understandable idea.

In some cases, brief sentences can also serve as a stylistic choice, creating impact or emphasis on a specific idea. Authors may intentionally choose simpler sentences to heighten the importance of the subject matter or to create a specific tone, rhythm, or narrative pace.

Overall, brief sentences play a significant role in effective communication, ensuring that ideas are conveyed clearly and concisely. They can be essential in academic, professional, and casual contexts, as well as an intentional stylistic choice in creative writing.

Just days after the tragic crash of a Virgin spaceship that left one pilot dead, the company has released a photo showing they are hard at work on a new vessel. In a picture taken in Mojave, California, the shell of a new SpaceShipTwo is shown as it is carefully being constructed by a team from Virgin. At the same time, the company has announced they will be resuming tests of their experimental rocket-powered spaceship in 2015. Scroll down for video. New model: A look at Virgin's new SpaceShipTwo being built in Mojave, California (above) Back to work: Virgin Galactic CEO George Whitesides (above) says tests on the new ship may begin in as little as six months. High flying: The original SpaceShipTwo (above) was destroyed in a tragic crash on Friday. The team has already spent a good two years hard at work in the company's assembly facility building the ship, dubbed SpaceShipTwo Serial No. 2, which will now replace the destroyed version. According to Virgin Galactic CEO George Whitesides, this new ship could be tested in as soon as six months. 'There was no question it was a tragic setback, but it's one from which we can recover,' said Whitesides. 'With Serial No. 2, we'll be putting a stronger, even better ship into initial commercial service and I think we'll be able to get back into test flights soon and carry forward.' In the meantime, the team at Virgin will still be able to fly and test their mother ship WhiteKnightTwo, as federal investigators look into the cause of Friday's deadly crash. Back to the beginning: a photo from 2008 shows the original SpaceShipTwo being built (above) Tragic end: The crash on Friday killed pilot Michael Alsbury (above) That crash left pilot Michael Alsbury, 39, dead, and his co-pilot, Peter Siebold, injured. Siebold somehow managed to escape the crash with nothing more than a broken shoulder, this after falling 50,000 feet with nothing but a parachute. He was discharged from the hospital on Monday. The investigation into what caused the crash could take up to a year.

system_prompt: You are an AI assistant. You should describe the task and explain your answer. While answering a multiple choice question, first output the correct answer(s). Then explain why other answers are wrong. You might need to use additional knowledge to answer the question.
question:
A misdemeanor (American English, spelled misdemeanour in British English) is any ``lesser'' criminal act in some common law legal systems. Misdemeanors are generally punished less severely than felonies, but theoretically more so than administrative infractions (also known as minor, petty, or summary offences) and regulatory offences. Many misdemeanors are punished with monetary fines.

Multi-choice problem: Is it true that is a felony the same as a misdemeanor?

Choices: (1). no; (2). yes;
The answer is:
response:
(1). no;

A felony is not the same as a misdemeanor. In the legal systems of many countries, including the United States and the United Kingdom, criminal offenses are categorized into different levels of severity. Felonies are considered more serious crimes, while misdemeanors are considered less serious. Felonies often carry more severe penalties, such as longer prison sentences, compared to misdemeanors, which generally have lighter penalties, like fines or short-term imprisonment.
instruct_model_response: The answer is (1). no. A felony is a more serious criminal offense than a misdemeanor. Felonies are punishable by imprisonment for more than one year, while misdemeanors are punishable by imprisonment for one year or less, or by a fine. The difference between a felony and a misdemeanor can also be found in the way they are charged and tried. Felonies are typically charged by indictment, while misdemeanors can be charged by either indictment or information. Felonies also typically require a jury trial, while misdemeanors can be tried by a judge or jury.
openorca_model_response:
(1). no;

It is not true that a felony is the same as a misdemeanor. While both are criminal acts, they are quite different in terms of severity and punishment. Felonies are considered more serious offenses, and are generally punished more severely than misdemeanors. They can lead to significant prison sentences, while misdemeanors typically result in monetary fines or shorter, less severe punishments. Misdemeanors include less serious crimes such as minor assaults, theft, and disorderly conduct.

Also during this time, a joint US/UK code-breaking effort (the Venona project)—with which the FBI was heavily involved—broke Soviet diplomatic and intelligence communications codes, allowing the US and British governments to read Soviet communications. This effort confirmed the existence of Americans working in the United States for Soviet intelligence. Hoover was administering this project but failed to notify the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) until 1952. Another notable case is the arrest of Soviet spy Rudolf Abel in 1957. The discovery of Soviet spies operating in the US allowed Hoover to pursue his longstanding obsession with the threat he perceived from the American Left, ranging from Communist Party of the United States of America (CPUSA) union organizers to American liberals.

system_prompt: You are an AI assistant. You will be given a task. You must generate a detailed and long answer.
question:
A Slew of Staph Infections Tackles the NFL
The NFL is learning the hard way that a microscopic foe can be much more imposing than a 300-pound lineman, as a sudden slew of staph infections has sacked several players in the game.

Early this week, Cleveland Browns tight end Kellen Winslow Jr. revealed that staph (short for Staphylococcus) infection had sent him to the Cleveland Clinic for three days, and he accused the Browns of asking him to cover it up. Pro football teams are notoriously reluctant to reveal any information on player injuries, but since six different Browns have caught the bug since 2005  Winslow has had it twice  the team's medical management looked suspect to some observers. "There's obviously a problem [with staph] and we have to fix it," Winslow told the Cleveland Plain Dealer. "Just look at the history around here. It's unfortunate, because it happens time and time again." The Browns, who denied that they had kept the news of his infection from his teammates, suspended Winslow one game for his rant, which included his claim that he felt like he had been treated like "a piece of meat."

But the Winslow medical controversy wasn't even the worst of it for the league. In the past week, it has become clear that two of its most marketable stars, marquee quarterbacks Tom Brady and Peyton Manning, had gotten infections. The New England Patriots' Brady has had at least two additional infection-related procedures since his initial season-ending knee surgery in September. It's now possible that his knee will have to undergo another operation, which could delay his return until 2010. Staph seems to be the likely culprit, but neither Brady nor the Patriots will confirm that. During training camp staph infected a bursa sac, which acts as a cushion between bones, in Manning's left knee. The infection required surgery and forced him to miss most of the preseason. Though the Colts released a statement on Friday insisting Manning didn't contract a more perilous staph, the anti-biotic resistant strain known as MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus), the incidents should alarm the NFL. "The NFL, and all the leagues, should be diligent, and not let their guards down," says Dr. Robert Gotlin, director of Orthopedic and Sports Rehabilitation at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City. "They've got to do better. It's got to be one of the top five priorities."

The recent cases have certainly gotten players' attention. "I'm concerned, and wondering why it's happening. It's not some little infection that goes away in a few days, it's pretty serious," says Chicago Bears rookie running back Matt Forte. The league is quick to point out that it has partnered with teams to educate players about the bacteria, while the players' union insists it's alarmed and has contacted the league about further action. Some teams, like the Colts, have posted pictures on training room walls that warn players about staph symptoms and how to avoid contracting or spreading it. For their part, the Browns note that the team has previously used a special anti-staph agent to disinfect the locker room, weight room and other places where players gather.

Staph, of course, is far from just an NFL problem. Two college teams, the '05 Florida Gators and the '03 USC Trojans, had multiple cases. And football is by no means the only sports victim. The infection kept Toronto Blue Jays outfielder Alex Rios out of the 2006 All-Star Game. A few days later another Toronto player caught it, and the clubhouse was disinfected. NBA players Paul Pierce, Grant Hill and Drew Gooden have had it. Staph killed a high school wrestler in California this summer, and last spring 15 students at a Pennsylvania high school were either treated for staph or symptoms caused by the virus.

What exactly are staph infections? Staph is bacteria carried on the skin, which can enter the body through a cut or during a medical procedure, causing the infection. Most are minor, but certain strains are particularly resistant to anti-biotics and can cause athletes to miss significant playing time. Athletes are more likely to suffer cuts, and the locker room setting bunches players close to one another in a warm, damp environment, so they are especially susceptible to spreading the bacteria. Since football teams carry some 55 players on their rosters, and tend to have a higher degree of serious injuries to deal with, they are at particular risk. According to a 2005 survey by the NFL Team Physicians Society, 13 out of 30 teams that responded had had a player contract MRSA in recent years, for a total of 60 leaguewide infections.

Though Philadelphia Eagles linebacker Omar Gaither rightly points out that "we're just a naturally dirty sport," there are several basic precautions athletes can take to lower the chance of catching an infection. Many athletes shave their ankles, legs, and arms because they don't want athletic tape ripping hair off their bodies, but experts say they should lose the razor. "No matter how careful the shaving is, you can have nicks and microscopic cuts in the skin," says Dr. Daniel Sexton, an infectious disease specialist at the Duke University Medical Center, who consults for an NFL team and several college programs. "Any time you break that barrier, it becomes a portal through which bacteria can gain access." Staph prevention is pretty low-tech. "You know, this is pretty simple," Sexton says. "Hand washing remains the primary defense against the transmissions of most organisms, including staph. Most people don't think of a locker room as a place where hand hygiene is important, but locker rooms are also mini-emergency rooms."

In 2003, a team of researchers tracked the St. Louis Rams and found five players who caught eight MRSA infections. "We observed a lack of regular access to hand hygiene (i.e., soap and water or alcohol-based hand gels) for trainers who provided wound care," they wrote in The New England Journal of Medicine. Other offenses included "skipping of showers by players before the use of communal whirlpools; and sharing or towels  all factors that might facilitate the transmission of infection in this setting."

In short: use a little common sense, tough guys. But when it comes to infectious germs, even a 245-lb. bruiser like Gaither believes you can't always outrun them. "You can't worry about it to death," he says. "It's not like you can walk around and put gloves on your hand every 10 seconds. Sometimes, there's just not that much you can do." Except hope that these recent cases are a coincidental hiccup, and not an epidemic that seriously tackles the NFL.

(See pictures of the week here.)
What was this article about?
response: This article discusses the issue of staph infections becoming a growing concern in the NFL. Several players, including Cleveland Browns' tight end Kellen Winslow Jr., New England Patriots' Tom Brady, and Indianapolis Colts' Peyton Manning, have contracted infections due to Staphylococcus (staph) bacteria in recent years. The article highlights the possible reasons behind the spread of these infections, such as the warm, damp environment of locker rooms, large team rosters allowing for easier transmission, and athletes being more susceptible to cuts and infection entry points. Precautions and preventive measures are also discussed, emphasizing the importance of hand hygiene and not sharing towels or other personal items. The concern extends beyond the NFL, as staph infections have also plagued college football teams and athletes in other sports. The article calls for improved preventive strategies and education about staph infections in the league to protect players and prevent a potential epidemic affecting the NFL.
instruct_model_response: The article is about a recent outbreak of staph infections in the National Football League (NFL). Several players, including Cleveland Browns tight end Kellen Winslow Jr., New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady, and Indianapolis Colts quarterback Peyton Manning, have been infected with staph. The article discusses the potential causes of the outbreak, including close contact between players in the locker room and the use of shared equipment. It also provides advice for athletes on how to prevent staph infections, such as washing their hands regularly and avoiding sharing towels. The article concludes by expressing concern about the potential long-term effects of staph infections on the NFL and its players.

system_prompt: You are an AI assistant. You will be given a task. You must generate a detailed and long answer.
question: Write down the solution for this math problem: Solve 276 - 48 = -38*n for n.
response:
To solve the equation 276 - 48 = -38 * n for n, we will first simplify the equation and then isolate the variable n.

Step 1: Simplify the equation

Subtract 48 from 276:

276 - 48 = 228

So the simplified equation is:

228 = -38 * n

Step 2: Isolate the variable n

To isolate the variable n, we will divide both sides of the equation by -38.

228 / -38 = (-38 * n) / -38

Step 3: Calculate n

Now we can calculate the value of n:

-(228 / 38) = n

-6 = n

So, the value of n in the given equation 276 - 48 = -38 * n is n = -6.
instruct_model_response:
To solve the equation 276 - 48 = -38*n for n, we need to isolate n on one side of the equation. 

First, we can add 48 to both sides of the equation: 

276 - 48 + 48 = -38*n + 48 

This simplifies to: 

276 = -38*n + 48 

Next, we can subtract 48 from both sides of the equation: 

276 - 48 = -38*n 

This simplifies to: 

228 = -38*n 

Now, we can divide both sides of the equation by -38 to isolate n: 

228 / -38 = n 

This simplifies to: 

-6 = n 

Therefore, the solution to the equation 276 - 48 = -38*n for n is -6.
openorca_model_response:
To solve the equation 276 - 48 = -38*n for n, first you need to simplify the left side of the equation. 

Step 1: Simplify
276 - 48 = 228

So, the equation now becomes:
228 = -38*n

Step 2: Isolate the variable n
In order to isolate n, we need to divide both sides of the equation by -38.

228 / -38 = -38 * n / -38

-6 = n

So, the solution for n is -6.

question:

The proceedings were taken up with prosecutors outlining their case against Amrozi , reading 33 pages of documents outlining allegations against him .

response:
b. yes.

Step 1: Identify the main components of each sentence
Sentence 1: The proceedings, taken up with prosecutors outlining their case, against Amrozi, 33 pages of documents.
Sentence 2: Proceedings, taken up with prosecutors outlining their case, against Amrozi, 33-page accusation letter.

Step 2: Compare each component
Both sentences mention "proceedings" and "prosecutors outlining their case against Amrozi." The main difference is the describing of the allegations: "33 pages of documents" in the first sentence, and "a 33-page accusation letter" in the second sentence.

Step 3: Assess the difference
Although the wording of the allegations description is different, the meaning of both phrases is similar: they both indicate a document or documents that outline the allegations against Amrozi and the length or size of the documents is 33 pages.

Conclusion: The two sentences have the same meaning, despite the slight difference in wording.
instruct_model_response:
The two sentences have slightly different meanings.

In the first sentence, the prosecutors are presenting their case against Amrozi and reading out documents that outline the allegations against him. The documents are likely to be more detailed and comprehensive than an accusation letter.

In the second sentence, the prosecutors are also presenting their case against Amrozi, but they are reading out a specific document called an accusation letter. This document is likely to be a concise summary of the allegations against Amrozi, rather than a detailed list of all the evidence against him.

Therefore, the correct answer is (a) no, the two sentences do not have the same meaning.

system_prompt: You are an AI assistant. User will you give you a task. Your goal is to complete the task as faithfully as you can. While performing the task think step-by-step and justify your steps.
question:
Pick the option in line with common sense to answer the question. Question: The person worked hard and achieved his goals and got to feel what? Options:  A. headache  B. disappointed  C. celebrated  D. simplicity  E. fulfilled
The answer to this question is:
response:
C. celebrated

Step 1: Analyze the question and options.

First, the question describes a person who worked hard and achieved their goals. The next part of the question asks how the person "got to feel" as a result of this accomplishment. The options provided are: headache, disappointed, celebrated, simplicity, and fulfilled.

Step 2: Eliminate irrelevant options.

A headache (A) is a physical sensation and not a feeling directly linked to achieving goals. Disappointment (B) is a feeling associated with failure or unmet expectations, which contradicts the situation described in the question. Simplicity (D) is not a feeling but rather a characteristic of something being uncomplicated or easy to understand.

Step 3: Choose the most appropriate option among the remaining choices.

Between "celebrated" (C) and "fulfilled" (E), both are valid feelings following the achievement of goals. However, "celebrated" conveys a more direct, in-the-moment feeling of happiness and recognition of one's achievements, which is more in line with common sense. Fulfilled, while also an appropriate response, focuses more on a long term contentment instead of the immediate feeling after achieving a goal. Thus, C is the most in line with common sense.
instruct_model_response: The answer to this question is C. celebrated. When a person works hard and achieves their goals, it is common to feel a sense of accomplishment and satisfaction, which can lead to celebration. The other options do not align with this common sense understanding of the situation. Information:  - A video game is an electronic game that involves human or animal interaction with a user interface to generate visual feedback on a video device such as a TV screen or computer monitor. The word "video" in "video game" traditionally referred to a raster display device, but as of the 2000s, it implies any type of display device that can produce two- or three-dimensional images. Some theorists categorize video games as an art form, but this designation is controversial.  - A film, also called a movie, motion picture, theatrical film or photoplay, is a series of still images which, when shown on a screen, creates the illusion of moving images due to the phi phenomenon. This optical illusion causes the audience to perceive continuous motion between separate objects viewed rapidly in succession. The process of filmmaking is both an art and an industry. A film is created by photographing actual scenes with a motion picture camera; by photographing drawings or miniature models using traditional animation techniques; by means of CGI and computer animation; or by a combination of some or all of these techniques and other visual effects.  - Fiction is the classification for any story or universe derived from imaginationin other words, not based strictly on history or fact. Fiction can be expressed in a variety of formats, including writings, live performances, films, television programs, animations, video games, and role-playing games, though the term originally and most commonly refers to the narrative forms of literature (see "literary" fiction), including the novel, novella, short story, and play. Fiction constitutes an act of creative invention, so that faithfulness to reality is not typically assumed; in other words, fiction is not expected to present only characters who are actual people or descriptions that are factually true. The context of fiction is generally open to interpretation, due to fiction's freedom from any necessary embedding in reality; however, some fictional works are claimed to be, or marketed as, historically or factually accurate, complicating the traditional distinction between fiction and non-fiction. Fiction is a classification or category, rather than a specific mode or genre, unless used in a narrower sense as a synonym for a particular literary fiction form.  - For the Robert A. Heinlein short story collection , see Expanded Universe ( Heinlein ) . The term expanded universe ( sometimes called an extended universe ) is generally used to denote the ' extension ' of a media franchise ( i.e. a television show , series of featured films , etc. ) with other media ( generally comics and original novels ) . This typically involves new adventures for existing characters already developed within the franchise ; however in some case entirely new characters and complex mythology are developed . This is not the same as an adaptation , which is a retelling of the same story , usually on a different medium . Nearly every media franchise with a committed fan base has some form of expanded universe . A very popular example of this is fan fictions . Fan fictions are stories created by a fan base that portrays existing characters in new and different ways .  - Literature, in its broadest sense, is any single body of written works. More restrictively, it is writing considered as an art form, or any single writing deemed to have artistic or intellectual value, often due to deploying language in ways that differ from ordinary usage. Its Latin root "literatura"/"litteratura" (derived itself from "littera": "letter" or "handwriting") was used to refer to all written accounts, though contemporary definitions extend the term to include texts that are spoken or sung (oral literature). Literature can be classified according to whether it is fiction or non-fiction and whether it is poetry or prose; it can be further distinguished according to major forms such as the novel, short story or drama; and works are often categorized according to historical periods or their adherence to certain aesthetic features or expectations (genre).  - A television program is a segment of content intended for broadcast on over-the-air, cable television, or Internet television, other than a commercial, trailer, or any other segment of content not serving as attraction for viewership. It may be a single production, or more commonly, a series of related productions (also called a television series or a television show).  - A media franchise is a set of related media in which several derivative works have been produced from an original creative work (usually that of fiction), such as a film, a work of literature, a television program or a video game. A media franchise is characterized by its components generally sharing a common fictional universe.   - A fictional universe is a self-consistent imaginary setting with events, and often other elements, that differ from the real world. It may also be called an imagined, constructed or fictional realm (or world). Fictional universes may appear in novels, comics, films, television shows, video games and other creative works.    Given the information above, choose from the list below the object entity that exhibits the relation 'subclass of' with the subject 'expanded universe'.  Choices: - animal  - animation  - camera  - classification  - combination  - computer monitor  - derivative  - device  - drama  - electronic game  - feedback  - fiction  - fictional universe  - film  - history  - illusion  - industry  - interaction  - interface  - internet  - internet television  - interpretation  - invention  - language  - latin  - letter  - literature  - media franchise  - mode  - motion  - optical illusion  - people  - phenomenon  - poetry  - program  - prose  - sense  - series  - set  - short story  - single  - television  - television program  - user interface  - value  - variety  - video  - video game  - visual effects  - word  - world

In "Laramie Shadows," a gripping and emotional Western drama, Tom Corbett (Franco Nero) returns to his hometown of Laramie Town, defying his late mother's wishes, to uncover the truth behind the mysterious message he received from family friend Carradine (Janos Bathra). Upon his arrival, Tom is confronted with the harsh reality that the once-prosperous town is now under the oppressive rule of the corrupt and tyrannical Scott family, led by patriarch Jason Scott (John McDouglas) and his sadistic son Junior (Nino Castelnuovo).

As Tom begins to unravel the dark secrets behind the Scotts' rise to power and their connection to his brother Jeff (George Hilton), he finds himself on a dangerous and treacherous path. With every step he takes, he begins to realize that his arrival has consequences not just for himself, but for the oppressed townsfolk who have been suffering under the Scotts' regime.

Driven by a burning desire for vengeance, Tom starts to form a ragtag group of allies, including the wise and enigmatic Chinese blacksmith Souko (Aysanoa Runachagwa) and the steadfast Indian housemaid Mercedes (Rina Franchetti).

The thrilling and action-packed journey sees Tom and his allies fight their way through numerous obstacles and confrontations with the Scotts' evil henchmen, culminating in an epic and suspenseful showdown between Tom and Junior Scott. As sides are drawn and loyalties are tested, Tom must ultimately decide what truly matters most: embracing the power of redemption and forgiveness or succumbing to the all-consuming darkness of revenge.

With its compelling characters and breathtaking landscapes, the movie seamlessly blends the raw, gritty spirit of the classic Western genre with a poignant and resonant story that will touch the hearts of audiences everywhere.

question: Solve -5*v + 499 = 469 for v.. What is the answer??
response:
Step 1: Identify the goal
The goal is to solve the equation -5*v + 499 = 469 for v.

Step 2: Isolate the variable (v) term
To do this, we need to get v by itself on one side of the equation. We should start by moving the constant term from the left side of the equation to the right side. We will subtract 499 from both sides:

-5*v + 499 - 499 = 469 - 499

This simplifies to:

-5*v = -30

Step 3: Solve for v
Now, we need to get rid of the coefficient of the variable (v), which is -5. We do this by dividing both sides of the equation by -5:

-5*v / -5 = -30 / -5

This simplifies to:

v = 6

So, the solution to the equation -5*v + 499 = 469 for v is v = 6.

2. Next, we need to solve for v. Since v is multiplied by -5, we can divide both sides of the equation by -5 to get:

v = 0 / -5

v = 0

So the answer is that v = 0.

Port locations are selected to optimize access to land and navigable water, for commercial demand, and for shelter from wind and waves. Ports with deeper water are rarer, but can handle larger ships. Since ports throughout history handled every kind of traffic, support and storage facilities vary widely, may extend for miles, and dominate the local economy. Some ports have an important military role.  - The London Plan is the statutory spatial development strategy for the Greater London area in the United Kingdom that is written by the Mayor of London and published by the Greater London Authority. The regional planning document was first published in final form on 10 February 2004. In addition to minor alterations, it was substantially revised and republished in February 2008 and again in July 2011. The London Plan published in July 2011 is currently in effect and has 2031 as a formal end date. minor alterations are being made to the plan to comply with the National Planning Policy Framework and other changes in national policy.  - A yacht is a recreational boat or ship. The term originates from the Dutch word "jacht" "hunt", and was originally defined as a light fast sailing vessel used by the Dutch navy to pursue pirates and other transgressors around and into the shallow waters of the Low Countries. After its selection by Charles II of England as the vessel to carry him to England from the Netherlands for his restoration in 1660 it came to be used to mean a vessel used to convey important persons.  - The Royal Thames Yacht Club ( RTYC ) is the oldest continuously operating yacht club in the United Kingdom . Its headquarters are located at 60 Knightsbridge , London , England , overlooking Hyde Park . The Club has a clear purpose : `` To provide the members with outstanding yacht cruising , racing and social opportunities in the UK and internationally , building on the Club 's unique heritage , central London facilities and close reciprocal relationships with other leading yacht clubs around the world . ''  - A sports club or sport club, sometimes athletics club or sports society or sports association, is a group of people formed for the purpose of playing sports. Instructions: In this task, you are given inputs i,j, and A, where i and j are integers and A is a list. You need to return the sum of all the numerical elements in the list A between the positions i and j (including positions i and j). Return 0 if no numerical element is present in the list between the given ranges. i and j will be non-negative, and will always have a value less than the length of A. i will always be less than j.
Input: 2, 8, ['3237', '3047', 'f', '9493', '8745', 'A', 'z', '3425', 'I']
Output:
response:
In this task, you are asked to find the sum of numerical elements in a given list A, between positions i and j, both positions included. If there are no numerical elements in that range, return 0. The input values i and j will always be non-negative and less than the length of A. Additionally, i will be less than j.

To complete this task, follow these simple steps:

1. Take the input values i, j, and A.
2. Initialize a variable to store the sum, call it 'sum_numerical'. Set its initial value to 0.
3. Loop through the elements of A starting from position i and going up to and including position j.
4. Within the loop, check if each element is a number. You can use the element's 'isdigit()' method to check if it's a numerical value.
   a. If the element is a number, convert it to an integer (using 'int()' function) and add it to 'sum_numerical'.
   b. If the element is not a number, continue to the next element in the loop without making any changes to 'sum_numerical'.
5. Once the loop is completed, return 'sum_numerical' as the final sum of numerical elements between positions i and j in the list A.

Example:

Input: i=2, j=8, A=['3237', '3047', 'f', '9493', '8745', 'A', 'z', '3425', 'I']

Step 1:
i = 2
j = 8
A = ['3237', '3047', 'f', '9493', '8745', 'A', 'z', '3425', 'I']

Step 2:
sum_numerical = 0

Step 3-4: Loop through A from position i to j
i = 2 (element 'f'): Not a number, continue
i = 3 (element '9493'): Is a number, add 9493 to sum_numerical (sum_numerical = 9493)
i = 4 (element '8745'): Is a number, add 8745 to sum_numerical (sum_numerical = 18238)
i = 5 (element 'A'): Not a number, continue
i = 6 (element 'z'): Not a number, continue
i = 7 (element '3425'): Is a number, add 3425 to sum_numerical (sum_numerical = 21663)

Step 5:
Return sum_numerical (21663)

Output: 21663
instruct_model_response:
Sure, I can help you with that!

So, you have been given a task to write a function that takes in three inputs: i, j, and A. i and j are integers, and A is a list. Your task is to return the sum of all the numerical elements in the list A between the positions i and j (including positions i and j). If no numerical element is present in the list between the given ranges, return 0.

Here are the guidelines you can follow to solve this task:

1. First, check if i and j are non-negative and if they have a value less than the length of A. If not, return 0.
2. Next, check if i is less than j. If not, return 0.
3. Initialize a variable sum to 0.
4. Loop through the list A from index i to index j (inclusive).
5. Check if the current element is a number. If it is, add it to the sum.
6. After the loop, return the sum.

Here's an example code in Python that implements these guidelines:
```python
def sum_list_range(i, j, A):
    if i < 0 or j < 0 or i >= len(A) or j >= len(A) or i >= j:
        return 0
    sum = 0
    for k in range(i, j+1):
        if A[k].isdigit():
            sum += int(A[k])
    return sum
```
You can call this function with the given inputs like this:
```python
A = ['3237', '3047', 'f', '9493', '8745', 'A', 'z', '3425', 'I']
i = 2
j = 8
print(sum_list_range(i, j, A))
```
This will output `3425`, which is the sum of the numerical elements in the list A between positions 2 and 8 (inclusive).

2. Go through the list A between positions i and j (including i and j).

system_prompt: You are an AI assistant. User will you give you a task. Your goal is to complete the task as faithfully as you can. While performing the task think step-by-step and justify your steps.
question:
Write an article based on this "Plans to introduce minimum unit pricing for alcohol in Scotland face further delay, following an initial ruling by Europe's highest court."

Article:
response:
Title: Further Delays in Implementing Minimum Unit Pricing for Alcohol in Scotland

Introduction

Plans to introduce minimum unit pricing (MUP) for alcohol in Scotland are facing additional setbacks, as Europe's highest court delivers an initial ruling against the proposal. The decision complicates the Scottish government's efforts to tackle alcohol-related harm in the country and raises questions about the future of MUP.

Step 1: Explaining the minimum unit pricing policy

Minimum unit pricing is a public health intervention aimed at reducing alcohol consumption by setting a minimum price at which alcohol can be sold. It targets cheap, high-strength alcoholic beverages that contribute significantly to alcohol-related harm. The Scottish government's proposed plan would establish a minimum price of 50p per unit of alcohol.

Step 2: Discussing the initial ruling by Europe's highest court

The European Court of Justice (ECJ) has issued a preliminary ruling suggesting that the Scottish government's MUP policy may violate European Union (EU) law. The court maintains that measures like MUP should be "proportional and targeted," considering alternative and less restrictive options to protect public health. Although the final decision rests with the national courts, the ECJ's ruling has a considerable impact on the legal argument for MUP.

Step 3: Highlighting the implications of the delay on public health

Scotland faces a significant burden in terms of alcohol-related harm; thus, MUP could be a valuable tool to improve public health outcomes. A delay in implementing MUP may lead to missed opportunities in reducing alcohol misuse and alleviating the strain on the National Health Service (NHS) resources.

Step 4: Presenting the stance of MUP's supporters and opponents

MUP's advocates argue that the policy would save lives, reduce hospital admissions and cut crime rates. On the other hand, opponents, including alcohol industry representatives, maintain that it would disproportionately affect moderate drinkers and impose an unfair burden on low-income households.

Step 5: Exploring alternative measures and potential next steps

As MUP faces further delay, the Scottish government and other stakeholders may need to consider alternative measures to tackle alcohol-related harm. Taxation, advertising restrictions, and educational campaigns could be part of a comprehensive strategy.

In conclusion, the implementation of minimum unit pricing for alcohol in Scotland has encountered significant legal hurdles following the initial ruling by Europe's highest court. As a result, the Scottish government may have to explore other avenues in its quest to address alcohol-related harm in the country.
instruct_model_response:
Plans to introduce minimum unit pricing for alcohol in Scotland face further delay, following an initial ruling by Europe's highest court.

The Scottish government had proposed a plan to introduce a minimum unit price for alcohol in an effort to reduce the number of deaths and harms associated with alcohol consumption. The plan would have set a minimum price per unit of alcohol, which would have made it more expensive to purchase alcohol in Scotland.

However, the plan faced legal challenges and was initially ruled upon by the European Court of Justice (ECJ) in 2012. The ECJ ruled that the plan was in violation of European Union (EU) law and could not be implemented.

Following the ruling, the Scottish government was forced to abandon the plan and instead focus on other measures to reduce alcohol-related harms. However, the issue of minimum unit pricing has remained a contentious one in Scotland, with some advocates continuing to push for the implementation of such a policy.

In recent years, the Scottish government has been working to address the issue of alcohol-related harms through other means, such as increasing taxes on alcohol and implementing stricter regulations on the sale and marketing of alcohol.

Despite these efforts, the issue of minimum unit pricing remains a topic of debate in Scotland. Some argue that it would be an effective way to reduce the number of deaths and harms associated with alcohol consumption, while others argue that it would be too expensive and could have unintended consequences.

Overall, the delay in the implementation of minimum unit pricing in Scotland highlights the complex and contentious nature of the issue. While the Scottish government continues to explore different measures to address the issue of alcohol-related harms, it remains to be seen whether minimum unit pricing will ultimately be implemented in the country.

Title: Europe's Highest Court Stalls Implementation of Minimum Unit Pricing for Alcohol in Scotland

Introduction:
The much-anticipated minimum unit pricing (MUP) policy for alcohol in Scotland is set to face a significant delay, following an initial ruling by Europe's highest court. This groundbreaking policy aims to reduce excessive alcohol consumption and its associated harms. However, it has faced considerable opposition and legal challenges since its inception.

Background and Context:
Minimum unit pricing is a public health measure designed to limit the quantity of alcohol available to consumers, thus encouraging responsible drinking. The Scottish government's proposal aims to set a minimum price of 50p per unit, with the expectation that this would reduce alcohol consumption and its associated negative consequences. These consequences can include alcohol-related hospital admissions, crime rates, and other harms that the government is seeking to mitigate.

First Ruling and Implications:
Europe's highest court, the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU), has delivered its initial ruling on this contentious policy. The court's intervention has prompted further delays, adding to the already long and complicated timeline for implementing the Scottish government's MUP policy. It remains unclear when minimum unit pricing will eventually come into effect, although it is now evident that the process will not be straightforward.

Opposition and Legal Challenges:
The MUP policy has faced significant opposition from various quarters, including brewers, wholesalers, and the alcohol industry. They have argued that the proposal disproportionately affects the industry and its consumers, particularly the responsible drinkers. In addition, the policy has been criticized by some sections of the population who view it as an infringement on individual freedoms.

As a result, legal challenges have been launched, questioning the legality of the policy under EU law. The Scottish government defended its proposal by arguing that it is a proportionate and effective measure aimed at protecting public health. It has highlighted that the policy is in line with similar measures used in other countries like Canada and Australia, where the approach has been successful in achieving the desired outcomes.

Conclusion:
With Europe's highest court issuing an initial ruling that brings further delay to the introduction of minimum unit pricing for alcohol in Scotland, the future of this policy remains uncertain. While the Scottish government maintains its belief in the efficacy of the MUP proposal, it faces a challenging battle both in the courts and in securing the public's support. The delay in the implementation of the MUP policy will inevitably prolong the debate over its merits, as well as highlighting ongoing issues around the role of alcohol in society and the challenges of implementing public health measures within the current political and legal frameworks.
